{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3334444,"name":"","username":"karamatH","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/cdc98d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-16T15:08:22.735Z","cooked":"

I have an intake that uses an HC-SR204 ultrasonic sensor, which I got from an XRP, and am now trying to use it on my robot. I wired the sensor to the DIO ports (5v,GND, Signal on port 0, and Signal on port 1) and then tried using WPI’s Ultrasonic class. However, I kept getting numbers like 0 or negative infinity and got no value changes when I put things in front of the sensor.

I checked the XRP code and noticed their XRPRangeFinder class doesn’t even use WPILib’s Ultrasonic class, and instead just makes use of one Analog input and doesn’t exactly show anything else.

When I used analog input in the same the XRP did, I wasn’t getting 0 or infinity. Instead, I was getting a value that seemed to change randomly. Looking back at it now, I assume this is because I didn’t exactly have any code to start the sensor send pings.

What can I do from here? I think there’s a possibility that I could have used the Ultrasonic class wrong, but I’m not quite sure. If the Ultrasonic class isn’t going to help me, then I might have to create my own version of the class. All suggestions are greatly appreciated!

My code for reference:

image1035×118 9.29 KB

image854×223 18 KB

Because this type of sensor timing can’t be done remotely, the XRP handles it in firmware and just mimics it as an analog input. The sensor datasheet indicates it’s a ping/echo type digital sensor. For Rio use, the Ultrasonic class should probably work–did you wire the trigger pulse input to the “ping” DIO channel for the Ultrasonic, and the echo pulse output to the “echo” DIO channel?

yeah, I connected to the trigger to the port that I labeled as ping

Looking at the Ultrasonic class internal timing versus the sensor specs, it definitely looks like it should work. The background thread sends a 10 us pulse at a 10 Hz rate, and a FPGA counter is used in semi-period mode to measure the echo pulse duration. So I’m not sure why it’s not working for you.
